text:
REFLECTION

Non luminous objects are only seen when they reflect or throw back light from a luminous object like the sun or candle light. Light shined on a non-luminous object is either absorbed, reflected or transmitted. Sometimes the combination of two.

-          If the surface of an object is opaque, the object absorbed light.

-          If it is transparent, it could transmit light.

-          1f the body transmits light, but such that an object cannot be seen through it. the body is translucent. 

The laws of reflection.

  1. The incident ray, the reflected ray and the normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
  2. The angle of incidence (i) is equal to the angle of reflection (r).

A real image is an image that can be caught on a screen. Light rays actually pass through a real image.

A virtual image is an image that cannot be caught on a screen. It is one through which rays of light do not actually pass but which is nevertheless visible to the eye. 

Images in a plane mirror are 

-          Perverted or laterally inverted 

-          Virtual (real image can be produced if the object is virtual)

-          Have the same size as the object

Two main type of reflection 

1. Regular reflection: parallel beam is reflected as a parallel beam. It occurs in smooth surfaces

2. Diffuse reflection: although a parallel beam may be incident on a surface, the reflected beam is not parallel. This happens with rough surfaces. The reason for the diffuse reflection is that because of the rough surface, different angle of incidence are presented to the incident beam, but at each point the laws of reflection are obeyed.

Moving mirror

If the incident ray has a constant direction and the mirror is rotated through an angle , the reflected ray is rotated through an angle 2 . 

The total number of images formed in two plane mirrors inclined at an angle , is given by (n) =  – 1

The principal focus (F) of a curved mirror is the point on the principal axis to which incident rays parallel and close to the principal axis coverage or from which they appear to diverge after reflection.

f =  = 

Note: 

  1. If the inner surface of the mirror is the polished and reflecting surface, it is a concave mirror.
  2. if the outer surface reflects, the mirror is a convex mirror
  3. the centre of curvature of the minor is the centre of the sphere radius of curvature

Formalion of image in curved mirror 

3 important rays are possible

  1. Rays parallel to the principal axis will be reflected by the mirror to pass through the principal focus.
  2. Rays passing through the centre of curvature of the mirror Will hit the mirror normally (this means angle of incidence is zero) and will be reflected back along the same path.
  3. Rays hitting the pole or any other part of mirror will be reflected ‘such that the laws of reflection are obeyed.

3 important rays are possible

  1. Rays parallel to the principal axis will be reflected by the mirror to pass through the principal focus.
  2. Rays passing through the center of curvature of the mirror Will hit the mirror normally (this means angle of incidence is zero) and will be reflected back along the same path.
  3. Rays hitting the pole or any other part of mirror will be reflected ‘such that the laws of reflection are obeyed

NB: 

In a concave mirror, if u > f; the image in the concave mirror is real while u< f, the image is virtual. The image in the convex mirror for object is virtual, erect and diminished.

 


Real is positive Notation.

Real is positive and virtual is negative sign. This means that all real objects, image and foci are positive while all virtual objects, images and foci are negative.

Real is positive Notation is an opposite of New cartesian notation, just master this one to avoid confusion.

Application of curved mirror

Concave Mirror

  1. Concave mirror is used as shaving mirror
  2. A parabolic mirror is a concave mirror used in searchlights and car headlamps. A parabolic produces a wide parallel beam of light at constant intensity.

Convex Mirror

  1. Convex mirrors are used as driving mirrors. They have a wide field of view.

 

Example

Convex mirrors are used as driving mirrors because images formed are

A. erect, virtual and diminished, B. erect, real and diminished, C. erect, virtual and magnified, D. inverted, virtual and diminished.

A. convex mirror 

 

Example

A ray of light is incident on a plane surface at an angle of 40°. What is the angle of reflection?

A. 40°, B. 80°, C. 200°, D. 50°

D (2014/2015, no 3).

Since angle of reflection is equal to the angle of incidence. Both angles are measured with respect to the normal to the mirror.

The angle of incidence = angle of reflection. Note that the given angle is not the angle of incidence. Given that the angle between the plane mirror and the incident ray is 40. Since the angle between the normal and the plane is 90. 

The angle of incident = 90 – 40= 50

Since the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection, the angle of reflection = 50.
